data: Integrated Intelligent Learning Environment for Reading and Writing

The aim of the project is to contribute towards a move away of traditional assistive software which uses a computer simply as an alternative to pen and paper and develop next generation learning software which uses a computer to facilitate the learning process for children with dyslexia and/or dysorthographia.
The ILearnRW learning environment will demonstrate the following features:
1. User modeling. A profile for each learner should be built. The profile should include, among others, the type of dyslexia and the errors the user is most likely to make.
2. Teaching strategies. The interaction of a learning system with a child should be based on a teaching strategy that supports the individual user in fulfilling her specific learning goals.
3. Classification of learning material. Content classification must be a major component in any content management system. To think about it, a tutor helping a child to learn reading/writing always selects appropriate learning material based on the child's needs and capabilities.
4. Personalized content presentation. If we know the errors the user is likely to make, we can enrich the text presentation with visual cues by combining highlighting, text-reformatting and word segmentation. In addition, the type of dyslexia should also influence the presentation.
5. Engaging learning activities. High degree of learner engagement is sought in any learning activity. To achieve this goal, we integrate learning activities into serious games. A creative game scenario, coupled with a positive reinforcement mechanism, will extend child's engagement.
6. Evaluation of learning. When a game is coupled with a game usage logging mechanism, data collected related to the user's actions may lead to a quantitative assessment of learning.
7. On-line resource bank. Coherent collections of data which support specific teaching strategies should be accessible to learners and educators.
The ILearnRW environment will support the English and Greek languages
Infrastructure and integrated tools for personalized learning of reading skill

The overarching aim of the iRead project is to develop a software infrastructure of personalised, adaptive technologies and a diverse set of applications for supporting learning and teaching of reading skills. The specific goals of the project proposed are to:
1.   Develop a scalable, cloud-based software infrastructure of open, interoperable components, including real-time user 
      modelling and domain knowledge components, to support learning of reading skills by children with different abilities and 
      linguistic backgrounds
2.   Develop domain models for English, Greek, German and Spanish learners, and to contextualise those models with 
      respect to skills and difficulties of (i) typically developing readers, (ii) English and Greek readers with dyslexia and (ii) 
      learners of English as a Foreign language.  The domain models will utilise and generalise the domain model 
      implemented in a previous FP7 project – iLearnRW  
3.   Develop applications for supporting learning (literacy games, interactive e-books, Reader app) that utilise the 
      infrastructure to yield different types of personalised learning services and experiences
4.   Develop and evaluate personalised content classification metrics that “enable reading” for use by electronic publishers 
      and libraries
5.   Enable orchestrated use of the learning applications (games, e-books, Reader app) based on learning analytics, and a 
      personalised experience through adaptive support
6.   Implement a number of large-scale evaluation pilots across European countries and providers in order to evaluate the 
      pedagogical effectiveness of the iRead ecosystem.
Improving skills of Academy players in Rugby Union via EU Co-operation

The mobility will be effectively planned, organised, monitored and evaluated by the mobility management team to ensure that the key learning outcomes as detailed on page 15 above have been achieved. Key to the evaluation process will be reports from the participants which will benchmark what learning objectives have been achieved and which will be compared and contrasted against the participants intended outcomes prior to the commencement of the mobility utilising questionnaires received post selection for the programme. Tables will be prepared to analyse the relative % success rates against each specific outcome. In addition all feedback from the participants, partners and management team will be collated and used to improve any future mobilities undertaken. 

The programme will be targeted at benefiting participants who are disadvantaged in the labour market which by virtue of the competitiveness of professional rugby union the learners inevitably are.  Often players come from socially deprived areas, have learning difficulties and have limited interest or ability in academic education. Each participant will benefit from improved employability, enhanced career progression and greater job security following the mobility. 

A key objective for participants is that they will benefit from up-skilling and improved employability and so WRFC will track participants' employment history for a period of three years updated annually, following the mobility in order to establish key data and trends regarding the direct correlation between a successful European mobility and improved employability. In addition WRFC teams performance will similarly be measured annually for a period of 3 years following the mobility. 

The Project Manager, Nick Johnston, High Performance Director, will be key to the evaluation process. Knowing the candidates personally and being on the mobility, he will be able to provide a balanced judgment in relation to individual benefits and enhanced learning for each participant. 

Following the mobility both participants and the partner organisations will be required to produce a final report identifying project outcomes and areas for improvement of future mobilities, critically assessing skills acquisition, language training and cultural integration.

All parties contributions will be correlated in an overall report evaluating the merits of the project in relation to the learning objectives and outcomes as well as identifying areas for improvement for subsequent coaching study visits within the EU. This final evaluation report will be publicised on the WRFC website.
Teachers who get immersed in new learning contexts will enrichen their students.

Title of the project: Teachers who get immersed in new learning contexts will enrichen their students.

Context: 
The mission of The  Wartburg College: 'We want our pupils to be valuable citizens of our society.' Where possible, we apply the standards and values which we derive from the Bible to the lives of the youngsters. Our pedagogical climate is featured by notions as: authority, love, responsibility and personality. We aim at a tailor-made approach for all types of pupils, quality of our education and the own responsibility of teachers.
Location Guido de Bres expresses  this as follows: 
- Room for education that takes place beyond the physical building.
- Room for deepening the Christian identity.
- Attention for the development of talents (during lessons, debating and extra subjects).
- Room for a wide range of educational activities and approach within the classroom: tto (bilingual education), veto (strengthened language education), and also a variety of didactics.

This has been worked out by the tto-team as follows:
The school wants to educate the tto-pupils who are capable to serve in the Dutch or international society.  
 
Being valuable as christian citizens implies: 
1. After three years the pupils have acquired a B2-level of English according to the ERK-model. 
2. The pupils are able to write and speak with insight on a diversity of European and International aspects. In this way they learn how to adjust to different cultures and make themselves subservient to their international environment. 
3. The pupils are educated in a challenging learning environment. 
4. Teachers point at the relevance of the English language in the national and international society. 

Aims: The tto-teachers will develop their English language skills and CLIL-didactics (Content and Language Integrated Learning) in order to raise the level of English of the pupils. Also the teachers will be able to dig deeper in the subject content. The French teacher will develop the principle 'doeltaal=voertaal', i.e. that he will speak the language during his lessons that he is also teaching. This will be made possible by a complete immersion in the French language and culture. Another aim is that pupils will grow in the way they give English output which will make it possible to participate in the society as European citizen.

Number of participants: 
Eleven teachers.

Activities:
- CLIL-course at the Hilderstone Institute. 
- Job shadowing at several English schools.
- Course French language and speaking skills. 

Methods:
- De CLIL-course exists of a 'Language' as well as a 'Methodology' part. It focuses on classroom English and also on how to give the right instructions when it comes to effective learning. On top of that the course offers a wide range of CLIL-didactics that will provides the teachers more tools to manage the educational process.
- The job shadowing exists of: the attending and observing of classes, the collecting of new classroom English and didactics and the collaboration with English teachers (discussing each others' lesson materials and lessons observed as well as the participation on moments of spiritual formation).
- Course French language and speaking skills. The course (FGUEE) exists of 28 lessons per week. Twenty lessons are related to the 
Français Général with pedagogical workshops of the Université d’Eté pour Enseignants Etrangers. On top of that workshops will be given on the area of culture, politics, guided tours in the region of Aix are organised and teachers get acquainted with the local culture. All lessons are given according to the ERK-model. After the course the teacher receives a certificate indicating the ERK-level of the teacher as wel as the number of lessons followed. 

Expected impact:
After the courses teachers will have made huge progress on the area of language skills, CLIL-didactics as well as international orientation. They will experience a personal, professional growth and this will enrichen the tto-education. In March 2016 we hope we will pass the inspection visit of the Ep-Nuffic team and therefore keep the label of tto-junior school. The impact will influence the veto-tam as well as the subject departments. On all these areas the new didactics will be shared, new authentic material will be handed out and a new impulses will be given to set up international projects.

Title of the project: Teachers who get immersed in new learning contexts will enrichen their students. Part III

Context: 
The Wartburg College states in its Strategic perspective: 'Customization for all types of pupils, quality of our education and personal responsibility of the teachers'. This has been worked out at our location by focusing on talents:
1) broadening: room for education that takes place outside the physical school building);
2) in-depth: room for deepening the Christian identity; attention must be paid to the development of talents (during the lessons, in extra study materials, debating, extra courses, etc.); and
3) multi dimensional: room for multi diminsional education in the classroom in tto and veto, but also a versatile didactics.
This has been elaborated by the tto team and applied in its own tto policy plan. The school wants to train the tto pupils to become citizens who are valuable and therefore serve in their international and own environment.

Being valuable as a Christian citizen in this context implies the following objectives for tto:
1) After three years, the pupils have the level of language proficiency that corresponds to level B2 of the European Reference Framework (ERK) for all sub-skills.
2) The pupils can talk and write with insight about a diversity of European and international aspects. In this way they learn a cultural empathy to serve themselves in their (international) environment. European and international orientation (EIO) takes place in the regular subject lessons, cross-curricular projects and international cooperation programs.
3) The students are reminded of the social relevance of the English language in the whole of the (global) society, in organizations and the business community and in further education.
4) The teachers offer high-quality learning material to constantly challenge the tto pupils.
5) In the classroom and at the school it becomes visible that the pupils are called by God to live not for themselves but for God and their neighbors. That is the guideline for learning for pupils and teachers. The question 'why do we learn a language?' we answer with: 'to serve God and to be a blessing to others'.

Aims:
The tto teachers will develop their English language skills and CLIL didactics (Content and Language Integrated Learning) in order to raise the level of English of the pupils. Also the teachers will be able to dig deeper in the subject content. Another aim is that pupils will grow in the way they give English output which will make it possible to participate in the society as European citizen.

Number of participants: 
14 teachers (6 CLIL course, 8 job shadowing; during two school years).

Activities:
1) CLIL course at the Hilderstone institute in Broadstairs. 
2) Job shadowing at several English schools.

Methods:
1) The CLIL course consists of a 'Language' as well as a 'Methodology' part. It focuses on classroom English and also on how to give the right instructions when it comes to effective learning. On top of that the course offers a wide range of CLIL-didactics that will provides the teachers more tools to manage the educational process.
2) The job shadowing consists of the attending and observing of classes, the collecting of new classroom English and didactics and the collaboration with English teachers (discussing each others' lesson materials and lessons observed as well as the participation on moments of spiritual formation).

Expected impact:
After the courses teachers will have made huge progress on the area of language skills, CLIL-didactics as well as international orientation. They will experience a personal, professional growth and this will enrichen the tto-education. The impact will influence the veto team as well as the subject departments. On all these areas the new didactics will be shared, new authentic material will be handed out and a new impulses will be given to set up international projects.

We have already had two successful KA1 applications that are connected to our present project. Our main goal this time is to develop skills to be able to introduce project-based learning on a wider scale at our school. We would like to gain experience via job shadowing mobilities. Our target schools are institutions where teachers already apply the methods required for project based learning. Moreover, we would like to participate on courses that will enable colleagues to acquire skills that will play an important role in teaching certain curricula using project methods.
It is a significant change in our new project that the majority of the applicants are not language teachers. Most teachers participating in this project are highly motivated and would like to improve their professional careers thank to the opportunities Erasmus+ offers. Their language skills grant their successful participation in courses.
We consider acquiring skills for project-based learning highly important as traditional teaching methods (frontal teaching, teaching based on assessment and memorising) are becoming less effective because it is more difficult to motivate students and as a result new skills for project-based learning are becoming essential.
This project would enable us to organise nine mobilities. However, due to dissemination, we expect that at least half of the teaching staff would be affected by the project. These nine mobilities are very diverse, though they serve the purposes of project based learning and they are all in the interest of our school. This initiative will have an impact on health prevention, school-parents relationship and it will also have a positive effect on informal learning.
In case our project is accepted, our school could become even more international and we could claim that 25% of our teaching staff have brought their professional horizons to a European level and they would have a wider insight into current trends in pedagogy. However, becoming an international school is already an ongoing process in case of our school. During this project cycle schools from abroad (especially from Poland, Germany and Great Britain) have inquired concerning job shadowing possibilities at our school. These cooperations originate from previous mobilities where our colleagues got in touch with local teachers.
Our headmistress takes part in our project this year as well. Her participation signals that our project is supported by our school leaders.
We would also like to highlight that international projects improve the language skills of our teaching staff. Taking part in a mobility will activate their language skills, in contrast with everyday teaching situations in which our language skills seem to deteriorate.
On the whole, we expect our project to help us make learning at János Xántus Bilingual Secondary School more entertaining. Experiential education and reformed teaching methods eventually will motivate students better and also improve their attitude to learning. Motivated and enthusiastic students perform better and they will have better chances in further education. All in all, students will be the winners of this project.
Kvalifikacijos tobulinimas sporto organizavimo ir mokymo specialistams

Sports specialists' professional skills development project will involve 47 different sports professionals, who work with professional athletes of all ages. This is viable, different in work experience, qualification and experience sports professionals. The project partners are sport organizations in European countries, which are, respectively leading in the sport discipline, have old traditions, or have better sports facilities, highest qualified professionals. The main objectives of the project are professional skills and key competencies development on work based learning, vocational training, update knowledge of work, to prepare training methodology for each sport, making long term cooperation with EU partners, acquiring sports management knowledge, improve English. It is expected that this project will help Lithuanian sport professionals to develop more competitive athletes, will expand professional competence in a new social and cultural environment, and will improve Lithuanian’s qualifications at international level. The skills acquired will let to adapt new teaching methodologies, to gain more experience in sport administration and management. This will encourage sport professionals, coaches and athletes increase their mastership and attract more interested individuals. Dissemination of the project results and obtained knowledge among colleagues, amateurs, athletes will allow sport managers, many trainers adapt these knowledge at their work with athletes, also ensure results transfer to other educational organizations. Involved partners in the project are Lithuanian sports organizations, in which working sport managers and sport trainers especially feel lack of knowledge, skills and qualifications, hosting organizations are reliable and well-known establishments in sport sphere– federations, clubs and universities, which will help to solve above mentioned problems.
